Award.AwardTitle: Biological Clocks: High Throughput Identification of Deterioration Markers and Dating of Museums' Proteinaceous Specimens
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry and Office of Multidisciplinary Activities, Dr. Moini and his group at Smithsonian Institution will address the need for tracking deterioration markers and dating of proteinaceous specimens for cultural heritage purposes. High throughput analytical techniques with high sensitivity, information-rich chemical detection and low sample consumption will be developed, and several categories of such markers will be validated. For a proof of concept, silk and wool textiles, as well as collagen and leather specimens, will be used as examples of museums' proteinaceous specimens. Specifically, this proposal proposes to study the three factors that track protein degradation at a molecular level - amino acid racemization (AAR), protein deamidation, and protein fragmentation (truncation) - using state-of-the-art separation and mass spectrometry techniques. Using a series of well-dated silk and wool textiles, spanning in age from approximately present day to 2,500 years ago, and collagen specimens from present to ~30,000 BP, the biological markers of deterioration will be identified as a reliable means of dating. To increase throughput and reduce sample consumption, ultrafast capillary electrophoresis mass spectrometry will be developed to take the place of conventional CE, reducing analysis time by an order of magnitude to about one minute. The techniques developed in this project may be applicable to other museums' proteinaceous specimens, including paint binder, paper, glue, proteins-based adhesives, etc. The development of reliable biological clocks has a wide range of practical applications including: food safety and biological dating of food supplies in the food industry; disease biomarker detection in hospitals and doctors' offices; and detection of biological contaminants in the environment.

The investigator will be engaged in outreach programs and demonstrations at local middle and high schools through his institution. The goal of these activities is to involve the broader community with the conservation process. Graduate and post graduate interns including underrepresented minority students will be encouraged to begin their research at the Smithsonian Institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to develop a new amino acid (AA) racemization technique for the dating of proteinaceous specimens. Radiocarbon (14C) dating is the most common technique for dating proteinaceous specimens.  However, the method requires large sample amounts, long sample preparation time, and can only analyze specimens ranging in age from ∼500-50,000 years. Decades ago, the amino acid racemization (AAR) dating technique was developed and applied to archeological and historic samples; however, the use of AAR for dating has been controversial because of reports of unreliable dating. To improve the accuracy of AA racemization dating, we have investigated several factors that may have contributed to the development of unreliable data.

 Amino Acid Racemization Dating 2.0

Firstly, we primarily used 14C-dated bones, or bones with established burial records. Secondly, for each species, we developed its own racemization calibration curve. Thirdly, we used a state-of-the-art separation technique based on capillary electrophoresis and MS for the separation of D/L AA, which is ~1000 times more sensitive than 14C dating. Fourthly, we checked sample purity using AA composition (Figure 1) and proteomics (Figure 2) analyses.  Fifthly, the experimental data for D/L AA was compared with the D/L AA predicted from the reversible, 1st order reaction.  

These criteria allow reliable dating of bone based using amino acid racemization (Figure 3). The curve in Figure 3 can now be used to date unknown human bone up to an age of ∼10, 000 years [1].

Development of Ultrafast Capillary Electrophoresis (UFCE) with Optical Isomer Resolution

Another goal of the proposal was to develop a portable ultrafast CE with optical isomer resolution to increase throughput.  The new UFCE fits in front of a mass spectrometer (Figure 4). The UFCE has two high-voltage power supplies, making it capable of operating in forward or reverse polarity modes. The portable UFCE provides high-resolution separation of selected amino acids and their optical isomers in ~1 min (Figure 5) [2].

Effect of radiation on Amino acid racemization

Yet another goal of the proposal was to study the effect(s) of radiation on AA racemization. Synchrotron x-ray and ion beam radiations have become the preferred techniques for the analysis of museum specimens. To study the effect of radiation on AA racemization, in collaboration with SOLEIL Synchrotron Facility and National University of Singapore, several specimens including AA, proteins, silk, and rabbit skin glue were examined. At macroscopic levels, both techniques produced similar color changes (Figure 6, Top Panel), indicating a similar mechanism of color change between the two radiations. At molecular levels, unlike synchrotron radiation, proton beam irradiation of free AA did not induce racemization; however, both X-ray and PB  caused significant racemization of AA in proteinaceous specimens.  The results show racemization is an important pathway for radiation damage in proteinaceous specimens [3, 4].  

 Broader Impacts

Our NSF support contributed significantly to the development of the new dating technique for proteinaceous specimens and has shed light on aging mechanisms of  specimens. In addition, it helped in the development of UFCE with optical isomer resolution.  Moreover, it helped initiate an international collaboration to study the effect of synchrotron X-ray and ion beam radiation on proteinaceous objects.  Also, one of my students gained tremendous international experience working with state-of-the-art technologies.  The results of the NSF funded research was presented at the International Atomic Energy headquarters in Vienna, Austria, and at the Louvre Museum, in Paris, France. The NSF support helped train several post-graduate interns and three graduate students with the state-of-the-art techniques.  Also, a large number of middle school and high school students from the DC area, as well as many researchers from local government and academic institutions, visited the lab and were educated on this NSF supported research.  Broader research impacts included the application of the high resolution CE-MS that was developed for amino acid racemization dating to separation of illicit drugs including their optical isomers as well as separation of high explosives [5-7].

References

  1. Mehdi Moini, Christopher Rollman, and Christine France, Anal Chem. 2013, 85, 11211-5.
  2. Mehdi Moini, Christopher Rollman, Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry, 2015, 29, 304–310.
  3. Mehdi Moini,* Christopher M. Rollman, and Loïc Bertrand Anal. Chem. 2014, 86, 9417−9422.
  4. Loic BERTRAND, Sebastian SCHOEDER, Demetrios ANGLOS, Mark BREESE, Koen JANSSENS, Mehdi MOINI, Aliz SIMON, TrAC Trends in Analytical Chemistry,  2015, 66, 128–145.
  5. Karen Brensinger, Christopher Rollman, Christine Copper, Ashton Genzman, Jacqueline Rine, Ira Lurie, Mehdi Moini*, Forensic Science International 2016, 258, 74-79.            
  6. Mehdi Moini* and Chris Rollman, Journal of American Society for Mass Spectrometry 2016, 27, 388-393.
  7. Rollman, C., Moini, M. Rapid Commun Mass Spectrom 2016, 30, 1-8.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The purpose of this project was to develop a new amino acid (AA) racemization technique for the dating of proteinaceous specimens. Radiocarbon (14C) dating is the most common technique for dating proteinaceous specimens. However, the method requires large sample amounts, long sample preparation time, and can only analyze specimens ranging in age from ∼500-50,000 years. Decades ago, the amino acid racemization (AAR) dating technique was developed and applied to archeological and historic samples; however, the use of AAR for dating has been controversial because of reports of unreliable dating. To improve the accuracy of AA racemization dating, we have investigated several factors that may have contributed to the development of unreliable data. Amino Acid Racemization Dating 2.0 Firstly, we primarily used 14C-dated bones, or bones with established burial records. Secondly, for each species, we developed its own racemization calibration curve. Thirdly, we used a state-of-the-art separation technique based on capillary electrophoresis and MS for the separation of D/L AA, which is ~1000 times more sensitive than 14C dating. Fourthly, we checked sample purity using AA composition (Figure 1) and proteomics (Figure 2) analyses. Fifthly, the experimental data for D/L AA was compared with the D/L AA predicted from the reversible, 1st order reaction. These criteria allow reliable dating of bone based using amino acid racemization (Figure 3). The curve in Figure 3 can now be used to date unknown human bone up to an age of ∼10, 000 years [1]. Development of Ultrafast Capillary Electrophoresis (UFCE) with Optical Isomer Resolution Another goal of the proposal was to develop a portable ultrafast CE with optical isomer resolution to increase throughput. The new UFCE fits in front of a mass spectrometer (Figure 4). The UFCE has two high-voltage power supplies, making it capable of operating in forward or reverse polarity modes. The portable UFCE provides high-resolution separation of selected amino acids and their optical isomers in ~1 min (Figure 5) [2]. Effect of radiation on Amino acid racemization Yet another goal of the proposal was to study the effect(s) of radiation on AA racemization. Synchrotron x-ray and ion beam radiations have become the preferred techniques for the analysis of museum specimens. To study the effect of radiation on AA racemization, in collaboration with SOLEIL Synchrotron Facility and National University of Singapore, several specimens including AA, proteins, silk, and rabbit skin glue were examined. At macroscopic levels, both techniques produced similar color changes (Figure 6, Top Panel), indicating a similar mechanism of color change between the two radiations. At molecular levels, unlike synchrotron radiation, proton beam irradiation of free AA did not induce racemization; however, both X-ray and PB caused significant racemization of AA in proteinaceous specimens. The results show racemization is an important pathway for radiation damage in proteinaceous specimens [3, 4]. Broader Impacts Our NSF support contributed significantly to the development of the new dating technique for proteinaceous specimens and has shed light on aging mechanisms of specimens. In addition, it helped in the development of UFCE with optical isomer resolution. Moreover, it helped initiate an international collaboration to study the effect of synchrotron X-ray and ion beam radiation on proteinaceous objects. Also, one of my students gained tremendous international experience working with state-of-the-art technologies. The results of the NSF funded research was presented at the International Atomic Energy headquarters in Vienna, Austria, and at the Louvre Museum, in Paris, France. The NSF support helped train several post-graduate interns and three graduate students with the state-of-the-art techniques. Also, a large number of middle school and high school students from the DC area, as well as many researchers from local government and academic institutions, visited the lab and were educated on this NSF supported research. Broader research impacts included the application of the high resolution CE-MS that was developed for amino acid racemization dating to separation of illicit drugs including their optical isomers as well as separation of high explosives [5-7].
